text: Pro tempore (abbreviated pro tem or p.t.) is a Latin phrase which means "for the time being" in English.Nancy Erickson; et al., Pro Tem: Presidents Pro Tempore of the United States Senate Since 1789 (Washington, DC: United States Government Printing Office, 2008), p. 7 This phrase is often used to describe a person who temporarily acts in place of an elected or appointed official. Should the official, a mayor for example, be absent or unavailable for any reason, the pro tempore becomes the acting official (acting mayor in this case). The president pro tempore of the United States Senate has been elected by the Senate since it began 1789. In academic use a professor pro tempore is usually a temporary position.Stephen R. Covey; Breck England, FranklinCovey Style Guide for Business and Technical Communication (Upper Saddle River, NJ: FranklinCovey, 2012), p. 5 In legal use a judge pro tempore is often an attorney who has been temporarily appointed by a judge.'Our State Bar Associations: The Washington State Bar Association', American Bar Association Journal, Vol. 48, No. 1 (January, 1962), p. 74 It is also found as a phrase in many kinds of documents to simply mean "for the time being." == References == Category:Latin phrases
title: Pro tempore
